content:
Probably fix your default SMTP server in account settings to be the same as the open used for other email.

I wrote the initial copy of that support article more than 10 years ago, I still will counsel anyone asking about using an out of office responder to not use the filter as you may well find yourself blocked as a SPAMMER as the filter does not know who you have responded to. So if you are away a day and get 20 email from the same person and each gets a reply out of office, next thing you know they will have clicked a spam button in their mail client and all your mail to them will be SPAM.

Server side vacation responders will send a single response per email sender, a filter will not.

content: Nella dir C:\Users\mionomeutente\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Windows\SendTo il collegamento a "Destinatario fax" reindirizza a "%windir%\system32\wfs.exe /SendTo" mentre il comando "Destinatario di posta", aperto con notepad, contiene solo il testo "MAIL" e comporta l'apertura della compilazione della mail con l'allegato, ma non attiva, in sostanza, thunderbird. L amial va compilata, chiedere la chiusura, salva come bozza, accedere alla bozza e finalmente cliccare invia. Non penso che il collegamento a ""C:\Program Files (x86)\Mozilla Thunderbird\thunderbird.exe" sia sufficiente, nel senso che, a me, apre solamente thunderbird, neanche la mail da spedire e tantomeno allega il file. Quindi penso che occorra il comando da aggiungere alla riga di comado "C:......\thunderbird.exe" per lanciare thunderbird aprendo contestualmente la mail con allegato.
creator: giuseppe6

content:
nel file "Destinatario di posta" nella dir "C:\Users\mionomeutente\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Windows\SendTo" (editabile come testo) scrivere: "C:\Program Files (x86)\Mozilla Thunderbird\thunderbird.exe" -compose.

L'unica cosa è che la mail (finalmente con allegato) rimane in secondo piano, sotto la pagina principale di Thunderbird!!!

SCUSATE: NON RISOLTO

content:
Put this code into your userChrome.css file:

tr[is="thread-row"] > td { 

 border-bottom: 0.5px solid gray !important;

}

If you're not familiar with CSS, follow these instructions.

First do this:

- go to TB menu > Settings > General

- scroll all the way down and click the 'Config editor' button on the right

- click 'Accept the risk and continue'

- search for: toolkit.legacyUserProfileCustomizations.stylesheets

- click the double arrow on the right to toggle the value to 'true'

Then:

- go to the Setup section of the FirefoxCSS subreddit tutorial (https://www.reddit.com/r/FirefoxCSS/wiki/index/tutorials/#wiki_setup)

- skip the instructions under 'Enable userChrome customization in about:config'; you've already done that

- follow the instructions under 'Locate and open your profile folder..'

- follow the instructions under 'Create the folder and its files' (make sure userChrome.css doesn't end with .txt - Windows must be set not to hide extensions for known file types)

- follow the instructions under 'Add some content to files', entering the code I mentioned above

- save the file and restart TB
creator: siffemoz

More suggestions please. Please note - it would be very laborious to have to edit each filter. I have several hundred filters. Some others reporting similar issues have many more; in one case more than a thousand.
creator: robert.heyward

content:
All I can suggest is this:

  1. highlight a receiving folder that is listed as unavailable in filter processing, rightclick and select properties and view the location,
  2. then, in windows file explorer, view the msgfilterrules.dat file and compare that with the other to see if there are differences.

My hope is that seeing the two may give ideas on what changes to make. If you're careful, some editing can be done directly on the filter. If you decide to do that, be sure to 1) exit thunderbird first, and 2) make a backup o the msgfilterules.dat file prior to making changes.
creator: davidsk

content:
Thanks @david. Your suggestion enabled me to find a solution, which I have set out below. I hope this may benefit others, who might encounter similar problems when transferring from old Windows 10 devices, to newer Windows 11 devices, for example.

1. Create a new folder within Thunderbird on the new device, and a new filter pointing a message towards it. 2. Close Thunderbird, and open msgFilterRules.dat with notepad. Immediately save a copy as backup if needed. 3. Compare the text of the new rule (conveniently at the start of the file), with previous rules. 3. For example new rule refers to actionValue="imap://me%40gmail.com@imap.gmail.com/INBOX/RecentFolder" 4. Whereas old imported rules refer to actionValue="imap://me%40gmail.com@imap.googlemail.com/INBOX/AncientFolder". 5. Replace all old-style references by new style references. 6. Also replace instances of =no by =yes (to reactivate suspended filters. 7. Save and exit notepad; restart Thunderbird.

My first attempt to edit (with libre office instead of notepad) was unsuccessful . Restarting Thunderbird showed an empty list of rules. Reasons are not known - but this emphasises the importance of making a backup.
creator: robert.heyward

content: Thanks for sharing this. Very useful reference. :)

content:
I don't use Yahoo, but there is a feature in gmail and AOL (based on Yahoo) where you can add an account as an allowed sender through the gmail/AOL smtp. In Yahoo webmail settings, look for an option like 'Send-only email address' which will allow a non-Yahoo account to send on the Yahoo smtp.

The other option is to set up separate smtp servers in TB so that each account sends on an smtp with a matching User Name, e.g. the hostmonster account sends on the hostmonster smtp.
